description.narrative:
A number of factors negatively impacts livelihoods in Taraba state, primary among them are human insecurity challenges and climate change. Human insecurity challenges and political instability result from prolonged skirmishes of ethno-religious and landresource-based conflicts, which are exacerbated by an influx of internally displaced persons (IDPs) fleeing the Boko Haram insurgencyin Northeast Nigeria, entering Taraba by way of neighbouring Adamawa state. Climatological uncertainties aggravate an already vulnerable agricultural system, as temperatures and the rainfall pattern and distribution become less predictable, and communities face cycles of flooding and drought which negatively decrease production and shut down market opportunities along commodity value chains, thereby placing the Global Acute Malnutrition status of the state within the stressed threshold. As such, the natural resources which poor people in rural areas depend on for their food security # land and water # are degrading in quality against a background of rising competition for their possession . The state#s population of over two million now live in communities that are experiencing increasedexposure to stressed food consumption status and their livelihoods is at crisis level, with levels of stunting in children at 43% (higher than the Nigerian average of 37%).
The population of Taraba State is heavilyreliant on the agricultural economy, though there is little reliable data to indicate exact numbers (one estimate is 80% ofthe population). The Taraba State Government has identified a number of challenges to food production levels, including: lack ofinfrastructure such as warehouses/silos and market facilities; inadequate supply and distribution of improved agro-inputs; lack of lack of organised markets and weak private sector participation in agricultural development activities; and prevalence of farmer-herder conflicts.
In the light of the above, Oxfam proposes togrow a resilient commodity value chain and rural enterprise model that will benefit small-scale farmers in Taraba state, Nigeria. The action will fast-track agricultural productivity,promote access to markets, increase income, and improve socioeconomic stability in selected communities within the state. Ultimately, small-scale farmers participating in this action will be able a) to produce (#PRO#) enough food to feed themselves andtheirhousehold; and b) produce a surplus of food that can be sold (#SELL#) into a market tosustain an income (together, #PROSELL#).

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib was founded in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Oxfam Novib is member of the Oxfam International confederation. Working together in the confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib's main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fundraising, campaigning and advocacy. Oxfam Novib’s the Hague office contributes towards this project’s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: Oxfam GB funding with back donor

legacy-data.name: project-name
legacy-data.value: PROSELL: EU Food Secur & Resil in Taraba

description.narrative: Shifted norms and attitudes: # citizens including people living in poverty and injustice, consider Farmers Rights (as in ITPGRFA) including plant genetic resources and freedom of farmers to operate in this field a fundamental rights for men & women.
role models / frontrunners expressing their views during events / on platforms organized by Oxfam and partners

Shifted norms and attitudes: # citizens including people living in poverty and injustice, consider Farmers Rights (as in ITPGRFA) including plant genetic resources and freedom of farmers to operate in this field a fundamental rights for men & women.

men, incl poor, consider (i) demand for sustainable Food production and access to sustainable food consumption, (ii) Land Rights and (iii) support to adopt to Climate Change fundamental rights for men & women

women,including people living in poverty and injustice, consider Farmers Rights (as in ITPGRFA) including plant genetic resources and freedom of farmers to operate in this field a fundamental rights for men & women.
